Hi Martin,

Thanks for the kind words about the paper and for incorpor=
ating it into a lecture already!

I am happy to try and answer your questio=
n, which relates to potential bounds on increasing evolvability and/or dive=
rsity. If I understand correctly, the underlying idea is that there may be =
a tension between evolvability and robustness; evolvability implies greater=
 phenotypic variability among offspring, while mutational robustness implie=
s stability even after genetic perturbation. In particular, evolvability mi=
ght be limited because too much of it would interfere with the ability to c=
onserve important features through canalization.

The way I think about it =
currently is that perhaps there is no ultimate tension, and that evolvabili=
ty can generally increase without limit. The reason is that canalization of=
 low-level mechanisms can act to increase evolvability. For example, many o=
f the mechanisms behind development are heavily conserved, but can generate=
 much phenotypic variability through being combined and modulated in variou=
s ways. In other words, modulating conserved features of development gives =
evolution higher-level levers that enable small genetic changes to be ampli=
fied and have a large meaningful phenotypic effect. Thus through continued =
evolution of the genotype/phenotype map, perhaps evolvability can continual=
ly increase (through exploiting canalization of lower-level mechanisms to g=
enerate increasingly high-level features). For example, heterochrony in bio=
logical development facilitates large-scale changes in size of different ev=
olutionary components through relatively small genetic changes (i.e. throug=
h mainly change the relative timing of events and not the mechanisms implem=
enting such events).

Of course, in the particular simulations that are app=
lied in the paper, there may be an ultimate limit to evolvability because w=
e are using a direct encoding and a simple measure of phenotypic distance. =
In particular, in NEAT the genotype/phenotype mapping is not subject to evo=
lution, and the above argument may not directly apply. 

However, I still i=
magine that the most evolvable ANNs in the models might be structured such =
that low-level behaviors (like avoiding walls) are somewhat canalized, whil=
e certain critical connections, when mutated, cause higher-level changes in=
 behavior (i.e. perhaps cause a change from left-handed wall-following to r=
ight-handed wall-following). Thus mutations in general may cause much great=
er variance in overall behavior. The particular features of the evolved ANN=
 architectures that result in greater evolvability in our simulations deser=
ves more investigation.

I hope this answer coherently addresses your inqui=
ry, I am still thinking through the implications of what you've brought up.=


Best,
Joel

wrote:
>
> Hi Joel,
> 
> Congratulations to this paper. I read it already, =
when you put it on arxiv, but great to see that it is now published as a re=
viewed paper. I think you very nicely demonstrated in the abstract and more=
 concrete model how evolvability can evolve without following any adaptive =
pressure. I really like how Ken and you investigate these fundamental princ=
iples in easy to understand simulations. And I am a bit proud to say that t=
he insights of this paper are already included in my Artificial Development=
 lecture. :-) 
> 
> Since you opened a thread for this paper I would like t=
o use this opportunity to ask a question that came to my mind, when I read =
it the first time:
> 
> From your simulations, one could falsely conclude t=
hat evolvability can and will increase infinitely (which is not a criticism=
 on your paper, because this was not the focus of your study). However, too=
 much evolvability would decrease the robustness in a genotype-phenotype ma=
pping (e.g. the ability to canalize), which possibly means that evolvabilit=
y only increases to a certain extent. Following this perspective, I was won=
dering whether in actual fact *diversity* is inevitable while evolvability =
in species will show a ceiling effect?
> 
> Best,
> Martin
> 
> 
> --- In n=
eat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <lehman.154@> wrote:
> >
> > Ken Stanley and=
 I are pleased to annouce our new article, "Evolvability is Inevitable: Inc=
reasing Evolvability without the Pressure to Adapt," which was published to=
day in PLoS ONE. The paper can be viewed at: 
> > 
> > http://dx.plos.org/1=
0.1371/journal.pone.0062186
> > 
> > The article applies both abstract simu=
lations and neuroevolution to explore a non-adaptive explanation for increa=
sing evolvability in nature. Interestingy, understanding evolvability (the =
capacity to further evolve) might lead not only to better understanding how=
 complex organisms evolve in nature, but may also provide insight into how =
to design evolutionary algorithms that are better able to evolve complex ar=
tifacts.
> > 
> > Most existing theories for evolvability increase depend u=
pon particular selective scenarios, such as a species surviving through con=
stantly changing environments. However, the insight in the article is that =
evolvability can instead arise spontaneously without natural selection acti=
ng at all. The main idea is that if evolvability is heritable, then evolvab=
le organisms separate themselves naturally from less evolvable organisms ov=
er time simply by their children becoming increasingly diverse and thereby =
spreading further through the space of possible phenotypes. That is, the sp=
ace of phenotypes itself can act like a filter that distinguishes evolvabil=
ity.
> > 
> > In this way, when novel phenotypes appear in the future, they=
 are most likely descendents of those that were evolvable in the past. The =
result is that evolvable species accumulate over time even without selectiv=
e pressure. This idea is supported by a variety of simulations where evolva=
bility increases without any pressure for organisms to out-compete each oth=
er.
> > 
> > Those familiar with novelty search will notice some conceptual=
 parallels with Ken's and my previous work on searching without objectives.=
 Like novelty search, the proposed non-adaptive hypothesis for evolvability=
 may invite some controversy because adaptive explanations for evolvability=
 are intuitive and widely-held. For example, researchers often worry about =
what kind of selective pressure will lead to evolvability, even in discussi=
ons in this group. One implication of this work could be that such worrying=
 is unwarranted because the best way to get evolvability may sometimes be t=
o stop trying to select for it. In any case, despite any potential controve=
rsy, we hope that this alternate perspective leads to constructive discussi=
on and demonstrates the need to question the assumption that evolvability r=
equires particular selective scenarios for it to increase.
> > 
> > Joel
